title: Microplastics promote the invasiveness of invasive alien species under fluctuating water regime
content:
Our findings suggest that Microplastic (MP) pollution enhances the competitiveness of invasive alien species over the native species when exposed to pronounced dry–wet water cycle conditions, potentially affecting the composition and biodiversity of the ecosystems. Thus, controlling MP pollution should be a part of the management strategy to conserve biodiversity and ecosystems.


Abstract

Microplastic (MP) pollution and alien plant invasions are two important threats to terrestrial ecosystems. Microplastics alter the physical and chemical characteristics of soil, potentially affecting the performance of alien plants. However, previous studies have overlooked the impact of weather on invasive plants in areas polluted by MPs. With the global increase in extreme rainfall events, it is imperative to redefine the correlation between MPs and invasive plants. Here, we conducted an experiment in a climate chamber to examine the effects of MPs on the growth and development of both native and invasive alien plants under constant and fluctuating water regime (FWR). The FWR simulated extreme water pulses during the 2016–2020 growing seasons in Wuhan, China. Our results indicated that biomass accumulation and root development were influenced by water conditions and MP pollution in both invasive and native species. The extent of the effects varied between the two groups of plant species. FWR promoted plant growth and fine root development in invasive plants but reduced the maximum quantum efficiency of photosystem II (F v /F m ) and nonphotochemical quenching (NPQ) indices of native plants. Moreover, FWR attenuated the negative effects of polybutylene succinate (PBS, degradable MPs) on biomass and root characteristics (length, surface area and tips). FWR compensated the negative impacts of MPs on the total and below-ground biomass of the invasive species Paspalum dilatatum and Sphagneticola trilobata, but not on the native species. Consequently, invasive species showed better performance than native species in the fine root development of biomass growth and chlorophyll fluorescence under the combined effects of MPs and FWR. Synthesis and applications. Our findings suggest that MP pollution enhances the competitiveness of invasive alien species over the native species when exposed to pronounced dry–wet water cycle conditions, potentially affecting the composition and biodiversity of the ecosystems. Thus, controlling MP pollution should be a part of the management strategy to conserve biodiversity and ecosystems.

微塑料污染和外来植物入侵是陆地生态系统面临的两大威胁。微塑料改变了土壤的物理和化学特性，可能影响外来植物的生长。然而，以往的研究忽略了气候变化对受微塑料污染地区入侵植物的影响。随着全球极端降雨事件的增加，重新定义微塑料与入侵植物之间的关系迫在眉睫。 我们在人工气候室中开展了一项实验，以研究水分恒定和波动条件下微塑料对本地和外来入侵植物生长和发育的影响。其中，水分波动模拟了中国武汉2016-2020年生长季节的极端水脉冲。 结果表明，无论是外来种还是本地种，生物量积累和根系发育都受到水分条件和微塑料污染的影响。影响的程度在两组植物物种之间有所不同。水分波动促进了入侵植物的生长和细根发育，但降低了本地植物光系统II的最大量子效率(F v /F m )和非光化学猝灭(NPQ)指数。此外，水分波动还减弱了聚丁二酸丁二醇酯(PBS，属可降解微塑料)对生物量和根系特征(如，根长度、表面积和根尖数)的负面影响。水分波动减弱了微塑料对入侵种毛花雀稗(Paspalum dilatatum)和南美蟛蜞菊(Sphagneticola trilobata)总生物量和地下生物量的负面影响，但对本地种没有影响。因此，在微塑料和水分波动的共同作用下，入侵种在细根发育、生物量生长和叶绿素荧光方面表现均优于本地种。 综合与应用。我们的研究暗示，当暴露于明显的干湿水循环条件下，微塑料污染增强了外来入侵物种相对于本地物种的竞争力，可能影响生态系统的组成和生物多样性。因此，控制微塑料污染应该成为保护生物多样性和生态系统管理策略的一部分。
